title: 107_s2212
content: The Act is titled the "Indian Trust Asset and Trust Fund Management and Reform Act of 2002". It establishes a Deputy Secretary for Trust Management and Reform. The American Indian Trust Fund Management Reform Act of 1994 amends definitions in Section 2, including terms like Special trustee, Indian tribe, Secretary, Office, Bureau, and Department. The American Indian Trust Fund Management Reform Act of 1994 updates definitions in Section 2, including terms like Deputy Secretary, Reform Office, and Trust assets. The American Indian Trust Fund Management Reform Act of 1994 defines trust funds as funds held by the Secretary for the benefit of an Indian tribe or individual member pursuant to Federal law. Additionally, the Act establishes a Deputy Secretary for Trust Management and Reform. The American Indian Trust Fund Management Reform Act of 1994 establishes a Deputy Secretary for Trust Management and Reform. The American Indian Trust Fund Management Reform Act of 1994 creates the position of Deputy Secretary for Trust Management and Reform within the Department. The Deputy Secretary is appointed by the President with Senate approval for a 6-year term and can only be removed for good cause. They report directly to the Secretary and receive compensation determined by the Secretary. The Deputy Secretary for Trust Management and Reform oversees trust fund and asset matters, including administration, financial, and human resource issues. They also engage in government-to-government relations with Indian tribes and trust fund account holders. Staff with expertise in trust asset and fund management may be hired to assist in these duties. The Deputy Secretary may hire staff with expertise in trust asset and fund management, financial organization, and tribal policy as needed. The Deputy Secretary has overall management authority over trust asset and fund matters within the Department. This does not diminish the responsibilities of the Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Indian Affairs or the Special Trustee. The Office of Trust Reform Implementation and Oversight is established within the Office of the Secretary, headed by the Deputy Secretary. It supervises and directs activities related to Indian trust assets and funds, administering trust properties in accordance with title II. The Office of Trust Reform Implementation and Oversight, under the Deputy Secretary, oversees trust properties, funds, and assets for the benefit of Indian tribes and members. It mandates accurate inventory maintenance, prompt revenue posting, monthly statements, and annual audits of trust fund accounts. The Deputy Secretary oversees trust properties, funds, and assets for Indian tribes. The Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Indian Affairs, the Special Trustee, and other officials provide accurate information on trust funds. Regular consultation with trust fund account holders is ensured for maximum returns. Contracts and compacts are entered into as necessary. The Deputy Secretary oversees trust properties, funds, and assets for Indian tribes. Contracts and compacts can be entered into under the Indian Self-Determination Act or the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act for trust asset management by tribes. Authorization of appropriations is provided for necessary funding. An Advisory Board is established under the American Indian Trust Fund Management Reform Act. The American Indian Trust Fund Management Reform Act establishes an Advisory Board under SEC. 306. The Deputy Secretary will establish an advisory board consisting of 9 members to provide advice on trust reform matters. Members will be appointed after consulting with Indian tribes and organizations, with specific representation criteria. Each member will serve a 2-year term. The advisory board established by the Deputy Secretary will consist of 9 members serving 2-year terms and will not be subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The previous advisory board under the American Indian Trust Fund Management Reform Act of 1994 will terminate upon the enactment of this Act. Conforming amendments are made to section 302 of the Act. The Special Trustee shall report directly to the Deputy Secretary regarding trust fund management and reform. Amendments are made to the American Indian Trust Fund Management Reform Act of 1994. Amendments are made to the American Indian Trust Fund Management Reform Act of 1994 by redesignating subsections and striking subsection (f). SEC. 3. INDIAN PARTICIPATION IN TRUST FUND ACTIVITIES. Amendments to the American Indian Trust Fund Management Reform Act of 1994 include removing sections 202 and 203 and adding a new section 202 regarding participation of Indian tribes in trust fund and trust asset management activities. A 10-year Indian Trust Fund and Trust Asset Management and Monitoring Plan must be developed and implemented by Indian tribes through self-determination contracts. Tribes have discretion in the planning process and must obtain approval from individuals with interests in trust funds or assets. The Indian Trust Fund and Trust Asset Management Plan must be developed and implemented by tribes through self-determination contracts. Approval must be obtained from individuals with interests in trust funds or assets. The Plan includes determining funds held in trust, inventorying trust assets, setting tribal goals, and defining management objectives. The Indian Trust Fund and Trust Asset Management Plan must be developed by tribes through self-determination contracts. Plans should define critical values, identify objectives, outline actions, use existing research, and be completed within 3 years. Approved Plans govern the management of funds and assets held in trust without requiring termination of the trust relationship. The Indian Trust Fund and Trust Asset Management Plan does not terminate trust status of assets. Tribes managing funds in line with the Plan are not liable for losses. The Secretary must manage funds according to Plan goals, except when it conflicts with trust responsibilities. The Secretary must comply with tribal laws regarding the management of funds and assets held in trust, providing assistance in enforcement, notice to relevant parties, and requiring Federal officials to appear in tribal forums upon request by an Indian tribe. The Secretary may waive regulations conflicting with tribal laws or the Plan, but not if it violates Federal law or the Secretary's trust responsibility. This section does not waive US sovereign immunity or allow tribal justice systems to review the Secretary's actions. The Secretary must submit a report to the Senate and House Committees detailing the Department's efforts and consultation with Tribes and individual Indians regarding the implementation of this section. The Secretary must submit a report to the Senate and House Committees detailing the Department's efforts and consultation with Tribes and individual Indians regarding the implementation of this section, including any recommendations for further changes to the Act. The Secretary of the Interior must create regulations within one year of the Act's enactment to implement the amendments. These regulations must involve active participation from Indian tribes with trust funds and assets held by the Secretary.
